results.notes:
Growing in rich black soil and leaf litter in a seasonally flooded forest near Quercus sect. Quercus, Fagus grandifolia, Carya spp. and Acer saccharum. All structures inamyloid. Releasing abundant oil drops in Melzer’s reagent. Dimitic with clamped generative hyphae. Pileus smooth and zonate. Brown cystidioles absent. Metuloid cystidia absent. Gloeocystidia present and projecting slightly. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth. Spore measurements: (5.3) 5.5 – 6.8 (7.3) × (3.6) 4 – 4.8 (5.3) µm, Q = (1.2) 1.3 – 1.57 (1.6) ; N = 30, Me = 6.2 × 4.4 µm ; Qe = 1.4

Mirrored on iNaturalist at https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/7002166

results.notes:
Growing on decaying hardwood at exposed margin of mixed pine-hardwood forest.
Brackets up to 4.5 inches (11.5 cm) diameter; isolated and effused-reflexed hemispherical to irregular in shape; margins irregular but becoming smoother as brackets age.
Surface of young caps exhibit lumpy concentric zones that dominate radial striations; cream with zones of brown to dark gray-brown; surface texture appears ‘soapy.’ Surface of caps lose the dominant concentric lumpy zones and become smoother with age with radial striations persisting; colors fade to primarily white to cream with fine concentric zones of brown and gray-brown; surface texture appears dry. Old caps still exhibit raised concentric zones with persistent radial striations; white with very narrow concentric zones of gray color; surface texture slightly shiny.
Pore surface white when young, becoming cream-to-yellow with age. Pore walls become very slightly thicker with age.
Pores irregular to angular, 2-3/mm.
No distinctive odor
KOH (3%), no reaction.
ID confirmed by DNA sequencing. (DNA prepared by Tom Tran; hosted by Alan Rockefeller)

results.notes:
Russula delica Fr., Russulaceae, Agaricales. Local names: Груздь сухой, подгруздок белый, Short-stalked White Russula.
It is the main commercial mushroom of this National park and Akmola District (for winter store). I use the most typical photos of this popular folk mushroom.
White cap: 8-20cm wide when adult, slightly convex up to flattened and sunken in the centre, margins curved in, old one sometimes becoming funnel-shaped; smooth, color from white up to yellowish-white or some brownish with dying. Old or dried damage makes weak dull brownish or yellowish coloring. Odor is pleasant. Flesh is white up to dull yellowish-white and loose when dying.
Gills: attached or slightly descending (when funnel-shaped), close to crowded; color from white and very light greenish-white up to dull yellowish-white. Young unit has rare weak white milk at gills, which makes later yellowish-brown points after damage on old gills. Spore print is white.
Stalk: 2-4cm long, white up to dull yellowish-white when old; 1.5-3.5cm thick, sometimes narrowing down, loose or hollow with edging.
Habitat: scattered small groups up to abundant in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
Edibility: good (special methods of cooking). Young one looks as Lactarius vellereus (Fr.) Fr., but it is not so strong and acrid.
Season: June – September.
results.location_name: Borovoye National Park, Akmola District, Kazakhstan

results.notes:
A scattered collection of fruiting bodies growing in a pure stand of white pines planted by the Civilian Conservation Corps at least 84 years ago. I recall there were two disjointed areas where I encountered this species. I didn’t look for other kinds of trees as the milky caps grew closer to the center of this large plantation; hardwoods, including some oak, were observed sporadically only on the periphery abutting the native pine-oak woods.
The exuded latex was white at first, changing to sulfur-yellow within a few seconds. The reported taste of the milk/flesh was allegedly mild, but it’s possible not enough time was given to experience the possibly acrid taste. I didn’t observe any vinaceous staining, but the habitat and the azonate to faintly zonate caps do suggest L. vinaceorufescens. The whitish stipes were flushed with pinkish-brown hues; this color scheme somewhat reminded me of that seen in Xanthoconium affine.
I doubt this collection was saved, but it was taken home for further study by J. & N. Burghardt.
results.location_name: Cape May Co., New Jersey, USA

results.notes: A single young and robust fruiting body growing on the edge of a pure stand of P. strobus planted by the Civilian Conservation Corps at least 84 years ago. There was a caespitose red oak standing just a few yards away; it still had plenty of green foliage, so one cannot rule it out as the host tree. This collection was preserved for RET.

results.notes: This is the largest of a cluster of very small (5.5 to 0.5 cm) caps from my yard, which is open ground 0f mainly Douglas Fir needles, some weeds and lawn mix with no lawn. White to cream colored convex cap with brownish center. Smooth, not sticky, not bruising a color, even margin, not striate. Gills are attached, light brownish gray, Stalk is white, lacks a ring, even, solid, neither rooting nor with rootlets. A cortina-like veil is present on a younger specimen, and the margin of the cap shows some small remnants of a veil. In sunlight they look almost pure white, but in the shade the brown center shows up better. A. praecox is the most common spring mushroom on my property, very close to this location too, but these are too small.

results.notes: Okay, I’m going out on a limb here. Don’t know if it’s even appropriate to try to identify an older specimen that is covered with mold/mildew. However, this one caught my eye because the moldy pattern on the cap has such an interesting pattern. I have tried to look for the basic features of this specimen wherever they can be seen/measured in spite of the mold. It is a solitary specimen initially appearing to be terrestrial but found to be fruiting from buried wood; mixed hardwoods surroundings. Cap: 8.5 cm., a beautiful shade of mahogany brown with a central depression, margin slightly inrolled; overlaid with an intricate pattern of what appears to be mold/mildew. Stipe: 3 cm. X 8 mm., essentially centered, stiff, brown, covered with short hairs best seen with 10X loupe magnification. Pore surface: almost entirely covered with the mold but visible enough to determine angular shape of pores, 3/mm. Did not try for chemical reaction or spore print due to the mold on all surfaces except stipe.

results.notes:
Russula rosacea (Pers.) Gray, Russulaceae, Agaricales. (Rosy Russula. Сыроежка розовая, сыроежка красная).
Cap: 5-12cm convex up to flattened and sunken in the centre, sometimes cushion-shaped with incurved margin when young, some sticky when wet, smooth; pink or purplish-red up to dull pink when old in wet weather, sometimes with dull lemon-yellow spots. Odour is weak and pleasant. Flesh is brittle, white, loose when dying, sometimes pinkish-white under skin.
Gills: attached and pinching out toward stalk, close to almost distant; moderately broad, colour from white up to dull yellowish-white when old.
Stalk: 4-8cm long, white up pinkish-white when old, mainly in dry weather; 1.5-3cm thick, usually enlarging down, loose or irregular hollow with aging.
Habitat: small group minor single scattered in pine-tree forest with some birches.
Edibility: good (several methods of cooking).
June – September.

results.notes:
A few features warn me away from Agaricus arvensis. It is out of season for this area and was found growing underneath a red alder and a pile of rotting Doug Fir bark. The base did not bruise yellowish, and the stalk and cap bruised reddish. No odor. Gill color also is off from Lincoff’s description. My first impression though was strong because of the appearance of the cap. The rest of the features could reflect A. arvensis.

Five mushrooms within ten feet of each other near a footpath through mainly Doug Fir/Madrone forest. 3 adjacent to and within a young set of Red Alder shoots. Two specimens taken from a pile of wet bark.

Caps 4 and 13 cm dia. , smooth, dry, white to pale yellowish to light brown in center. Even margin without remnants. Slow reddish bruising reaction. No odor. No radial lines on margin.

Stalks 10 and 18 cm in length, 0.8 and 2.0 cm min in diameter, smooth, white, even, with pendant ring near upper stalk, forming bulbous base. Bruise red. The color is superficial and rolls off like a membrane leaving a white surface beneath. Smaller (younger) mushroom’s ring flares outward, larger hangs and is stuck to the stalk. Both stipes break free of pileus easily and in longitudinal section are hollow and not yellowing when cut.

Gills. Free, crowded. Smaller pale grayish tan, larger a darker more reddish version.

Greenwood Neighborhood, Seattle, King Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
A single immature fruiting body growing along the Blue Trail in pine-oak woods. Macro-morphology puts this one into sect. Validae. This assignment in conjunction with the pleasant minty-fruity to anise-fruity odor suggests A. submaculata sensu Tulloss. It is an unusually late fruiting for this summer species (all MO posts reported from June through September). We literally see this taxon once in the blue moon in the Pine Barrens.
This collection was preserved for RET.

DNA Results & Discussion (posted on 26-Dec-20):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 685 bps was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this collection and posted to this observation. It consists of the last 46 characters of nrSSU, followed by the full-length ITS locus of 601 nucleotides and then by the first 38 bps of nrLSU. The ITS region is fully supported by either read, so just one of these sharp and pristine reads would have been enough. There are no ambiguities, it’s a single haplotype.
> A BLASTn search of the ITS sequence returned 9 accessions labeled as A. submaculata as top hits with 99.5-100% pairwise similarity and 96-100% query covers. Seven of these are associated with Stephen D. Russell’s vouchers. There are no GenBank accessions authored by Dr. Tulloss (RET) at this time.
> Discussion: The current species concept of A. submaculata is based on the research by RET. In particular, he writes:
“After more than 30 years of collecting in the eastern United States, RET has found only one entity that could correspond to Peck’s description of A. submaculata. Nevertheless, because of the limited description of the present species…, the identification has not been formally published.”1
Peck’s original description published in 1900 reads:
“Pileus convex or subcampanulate, glabrous, shining, even on the margin, dark brown, more or less marked by whitish stripes or spots; lamellae thin, subdistant, free, white; stem equal, bulbous, glabrous, solid, white, the annulus large, membranous, white. Pileus 7-9 cm. broad; stem 7-9 cm. long, 6-12 mm. thick. Scattered or cespitose. Thin wood and open places. North Carolina. July. Miss M. L. Wilson. The species is easily recognized by the white spots on the pileus. The specimen examined yielded no spores.”
MO261109 looks and smells like A. submaculata (sensu RET) and has the ITS sequence matching GenBank accessions of numerous collections identified as submaculata based on the modern species concept. Case closed!
1 http://amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20submaculata

results.notes: Found in soil near both pines and spruce on hospital grounds. No deciduous trees nearby. Large fruiting of possibly over 100 individuals (both singly and clustered). Cap sticky when wet, darker in the center. Cap size 4-6 cm., stipe (fibrous) about 3-5 cm. Some specimens fruiting singly and some clustered. Gills attached, close. Cap margin inrolled and white flakes at the apex of the stipe. Obtained copious brown spore print. Specimens sent to Dr. Henry Beker. He believes this is probably a Hebeloma, but not species curstuliniforme. Hope this can be determined eventually. On May 5, 2017 I received an e-mail from Professor Henry Beker. He identified the specimens I sent him as H. arenosum.

results.notes:
Christine Fischer, truffle researcher at the Forest Science Center of Catalonia, Spain, leads truffle and mushroom forays in Spain. These truffles were found using trained dogs. Christine identified the truffles and took the photos labeled T rufum, posted with her permission, in her laboratory.

Tuber rufum Pico:Fr.1823 var rufum
Fruit bodies are light-colored, small and sub-globose or irregular with very light reddish beige to brown with roughly-smooth surface made up of small, flattened warts. Found in spring through late autumn, growing with conifers and deciduous trees with wide range of habitats. Mild smoky odor.
There are at least 5 varieties of T. rufum described: apiculatum, rufum, ferrugineum, lucidum & nitidum.
Gleba pale white to pinkish or brownish-grey with cottony white marbling of sterile tissue, with gangliform pattern.
Ascus, with sinuous, long peduncle, 1-6 spores/ascus, most frequently 3-4 spores/ascus.
Spores are yellow brown, ellipsoid to roundish with spiny ornamentation, slightly curved at the distal end.
from Funghi Ipogei D’Europa
Amer Montecchi & Mario Sarasini
AMB Centro Studi Micologici

A trained dog was used to find the truffles.

results.notes:
Growing clustered and partially buried in black mulch under Tilia along a path near Taxus sp. Almost definitely mycorrhizal with Tilia sp. Odor like the base of a head of lettuce. Taste mealy and slightly bitter. Caps convex to nearly plane. Cap centers pale yellow-brown. Margin of cap white. Young cap margins inrolled but not mature caps. Caps not hygrophanous or rugulose. Lamellae white when young, maturing to light brown with white fimbriate edges. Lamellae adnate and about 0.3 cm deep. Stipes bulbous and with thick pruina arranged in ridges. Stipes not discoloring, not rooting, and without cortinas or mycelial cords. Stipe context white and slightly hollowed in the center.

results.notes:
Growing scattered and in small clusters mostly black mulch under Tilia along a path near Taxus sp. Almost definitely mycorrhizal with Tilia sp. 2 basidiocarps growing from a crack in the sidewalk. Odor potato-like. Taste mealy, nutty and earthy; somewhat like the seeds of Plantago spp. Caps convex and some with a slight umbo in the center. Caps not spotted and without universal veil remnants. Caps with golden-brown centers and whitish margins. Mature cap margins plant. The caps did not seem to be hygrophanous and weren’t rugulose. Did not notice tears in the lamellae or white fimbriate edges. The gill edges were lighter though. Stipes with relatively even widths throughout. Stipes not discoloring and without mycelial cords or universal veil remnants. Cortinas present and leaving some remnants on the stipes. I only found one mature specimen unless this is the same as the other small Hebeloma I found at the same location.

Basidiocarp measured:

results.notes:
Growing solitary in black mulch under Tilia along a path near Taxus sp. Almost definitely mycorrhizal with Tilia sp. Odor potato-like. Taste mealy. Cap plane and purple-brown over most of the disc except for a lighter center and a whitish margin. Cap margin inrolled. Cap not rugulose, not spotted, did not have universal veil remnants and did not seem to be hygrophanous. Lamellae adnexed, without tears and with a smooth white edge. Base of stipe tapered and discoloring yellowish-brown. Stipe not rooting, without universal veil remnants and without mycelial cords. Did not notice a cortina. Stipe context hith a white, hollow center and a buff exterior.

Basidiocarp measured:
-Pileus width: 1.9 cm
-Length of stipe: 2.0 cm
-Stipe width mid: 0.5 cm
-Sipe width base: 0.3 cm
-Length of full length lamellae: 0.7 cm

results.notes:
Found growing in a group on a fallen dead oak tree.

Cap: 4-15 cm; convex, becoming planoconvex or flat; dry; densely to sparsely covered with small, innate scales, especially over the center; brick red.

Gills: Attached to the stem by a notch; close; pale yellow at first, becoming deeper yellow and developing rusty brown discolorations; eventually becoming rusty overall.

Stem: 4-10 cm long; 4-14 mm thick; more or less equal; purplish pink near the apex, but brownish overall; fibrillose; with a flimsy, ephemeral ring or with a ring zone near the apex; basal mycelium white.

Flesh: Whitish; turning purplish pink in the cap when sliced.

Odor and Taste: Taste strongly bitter; odor not distinctive.

Spore Print: Bright orange-brown.

Odor and Taste: Taste strongly bitter; odor not distinctive.

results.notes:
Growing solitary to connate from well decayed log. Spore print pink. No discernable odor. Tastes very slightly spicy. Flesh thin, but appeared to be evenly colored throughout.
Cap: 6mm – 18mm. Umbilicate, decurved, dry, sericeous/fibrillose, even margin with uncinate, broad, thick, subdistant, even edged, unequal gills.
Stem: 10mm – 38mm X 2mm – 3mm. Central, round, equal, slightly clubbed, longitudinally striate, squamulous, and solid. Audible snap. White basal mycelium attached to foot.
DNA sequencing matches entry for Entoloma occidentale in GenBank. Sequence is:


Big thanks to Alan Rockefeller and Stephen Russell for assitance with verifying the results as a match to GenBank KU574742, which may not be correctly identified, and for interpreting the sequence above for sharing.

Microscopy and additional ITS sequencing by Ben McCormick was performed on Observation 452840.

results.notes:
Two examples on my drier.

Our CA novinupta is normally a late winter/spring fruiter. This is decidedly fall. But of course, it is also our only good (unusually early in October) rain in quite a while, after several drought years and only one recovery year last year, where very few MR sp. fruited, probably due to ongoing tree stress. Found in a mixed woodland with tan oak and redwood.

Cryptic sp. in our western blushers?

results.notes:
Ermahgerd! I couldn’t be happier! So a friend of mine posted a photo on facebook a couple of hours ago, because he wanted to share the photos he shot with his newly bought camera. A couple of flowers and insects, but also a mushroom. A white mushroom. A white mushroom with pointy scales on the pileus… And some sort of girdles of squamules on the stipe… An entirely white mushroom with pointy scales on the pileus and girdles of squamules on the STIPE?! That is Amanita vittadinii!!! Since the very beginning of my Fungi Fever, which has been going for over two decades, I have wanted to see this amazing, very rare amycorrhizal, Mediterranean species that only sporadically pops up in the coastal area of the Netherlands! And it was only 20 minutes away from where I needed to be at that moment?!

So I immediately messaged my friend to ask for location, which happened to be right around the corner from where he lives. Another very dear friend of mine, with whom I always go mushroom hunting, also said: I am going with you, no matter what! And off we went!

The young button was still standing, but two of the larger specimens were already kicked down by kids (those damn kids…). It did mean that I can take one of the specimens home for in my herbarium :) Nothing lost!

This awesome Amanita is rarely seen in the Netherlands, deemed extremely rare and listed as Near Threatened on the Dutch Red List (Arnolds & Veerkamp, 2008). Here’s the distribution in the Netherlands, for those who are interested!

https://www.verspreidingsatlas.nl/0003220

results.notes: Growing in mud in the trail near grasses, other herbaceous plants, spruce and aspen. Abundant along a small stretch of the trail. Some forming clusters joined at the base of the stem. Stems whitish with white pruina at the apex and not rooting. No veil remnants or annulus on the stem, Caps conic to convex and some with a slight umbo. Young caps starting off orange-brown with small fibrillose partial veil remnants (similar to the ones on young Psilocybe caerulipes) before fading to dull brown with a lighter margin and no veil remnants. Cap margin striate. Cap margins not inrolled at any point. Did not notice any bruising reaction. Young gills off-white and becoming dull brown to almost black with a whitish margin in maturity. Spore print on other caps appeared to be black in the field. Spores truncate. Pleurocystidia scattered on the gill faces and without acute apices, thickened walls or incrustations. I noticed more microscopic features and could post more spore measurements but the key is a mess. I think this might be something like P. psilocyboides or P. boulderensis. Photos taken 3 days after collection.

Code: Bot_667/2012_IMG1412

Habitat: grassland with some bushes and scattered trees, Pinus nigra, Picea abies, Ostrya carpinifolia, Fagus sylvatica, Corylus avellana most frequent; under a canopy of Pinus nigra; slightly inclined mountain slope, south aspect, fairly warm and dry place, in half shade; calcareous ground; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-10 deg C, elevation 610 m (2.000 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Bovec basin, east of the pastures at Plajer’s place, at the foot of Mt. Čukla, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Lactarius sanguifluus is relatively easy to recognize by its feature that its milk is blood red from scratch, not orange at the beginning and gradually turning to red, like in several other species with orange/red milk. It is mycorrhizal to Pinus sp.. Otherwise its color can vary widely from greenish, vinaceous, almost bluish, orange, yellowish ….

Growing in a fairly scattered group; about eight fruit bodies present; pilei diameter up to 10.5 cm, stipe up to 7 cm long; milk immediately red, almost not changing, after some time becoming slightly grayish; context quite brittle, after long time (hours) context becoming lightly greenish and at the base of the stipe slight, longitudinal, greenish strakes appear; SP light ocher.

Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

Pileus: 3.5 — 5.0 cm; planoconvex to undulating; uplifted with age; smooth/glabrous; Cinnamon color (6D6 as per Methuen Handbook of Color).

Gills: close; lamellulae in 3 series; adnexed with decurrent tooth; receding with age/desiccation; edge slightly uneven to gently scalloped.

Margin: undulating.

Context: 0.6 cm; white/creamy; fleshy, somewhat firm; breaking cleanly.

Odor: grassy/earthy; reminsicent of A. bisporus.

results.notes:
Paxillus involutus (Batsch) Fr., Paxillaceae, Agaricales. Locan names: cвинушка тонкая, свинушка, дунька, Poison Paxillus).
Cap: 8-20cm slightly convex up to flattened and sunken in the centre margins curved in, old one sometimes becoming funnel-shaped; young mushroom is fine velvety old one is usually smooth, colour from dull yellow or light brownish-yellow when young up to yellowish-brown or dull olive-brown. Bruising or other damage makes dark brown or reddish-brown colouring. Odour is weak and pleasant.
Flesh is light yellow, then dull brownish-yellow, reddish-brown when bruising, brownish-black after boiling.
Gills: descending, close up to crowded, narrow when young then moderately broad; colour from dull yellow up to yellowish-brown when old or after bruising.
Stalk: 3-6cm long, light yellow, then dull brownish-yellow, reddish-brown when bruising; 1.5-3cm thick, solid.
Habitat: common kind, small groups scattered in pine-tree forest near aspen and birch or in birch sites in wet places.
Edibility: published poisonous, but most of Russian people believe that it is good for food, because taste is good and no real data about any accidents with this kind. It is published in Russian Wikipedia about one deadly accident in Central Siberia, but it looks as a joke, because they have lots of King Bolete and don’t collect this kind at all). As I know, people who often used to eat this kind lived over 80.
Season: July – August.

results.notes:
Tricholoma zelleri (D.E. Stuntz & A.H. Sm.) Ovrebo & Tylutki, Tricholomataceae, Agaricales.
Local name: Рядовка опенковидная.
Cap: 5-16cm, rounded or convex up to broadly convex minor flat, very rare sunken; sometimes indistinct knob; colour is brownish-pink up to reddish-brown, sometimes multicoloured with some greenish-yellow spots. Cap surface is smooth with radial gentle light cracks; margins incurved with remnants of veil for young unit; flesh is thick.
Gills: attached, close and narrow; colour from white up to pinkish-white or cream when old. Veil: partial veil leaving membranous ragged ring on upper third of stalk.
Stalk: 3-7cm long, white up to pinkish-white above ring; 1.5-3cm thick, some enlarging to the centre and narrowing to the bottom that sometimes as a root; stalk is usually central and sometimes has indistinct concentrically rims. Stalk looks as covered under a ring with a reddish veil as a sock. Odour is unpleasant as bad laundry soap.
Edibility: not good coarse bad odour, people use boiling or fermentation with salting for winter store when better kinds are absent.
Habitat: small groups scattered in pine-tree forest.
results.location_name: Borovoye National Park, Akmola District, Kazakhstan
